intro: Silene douglasii var. villosa, commonly known as the Douglas's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It produces capsule fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Silene douglasii var. villosa is adapted to harsh conditions and plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat.
